subject: Career
title: Negotiation Communication: Interest vs. Position
description: One-minute skill: Negotiation Communication: Interest vs. Position.

hook.text: Two siblings fight over an orange. One wants the juice. The other wants the peel for baking. Both could win.

buildup.text: Fisher and Ury's 'Getting to Yes' introduced the concept: focus on interests, not positions.

discovery.text: Positions are what people say they want. Interests are why they want it. The why opens creative solutions.

twist.text: Most workplace negotiations are positional: 'I need this budget.' 'No.' End of discussion.

climax.text: Ask: 'Help me understand what you need this to accomplish.' The answer reveals interests you can satisfy.

punchline.text: Behind every position is an interest. Find it and you'll find the deal.

quiz.question: What's the difference between positions and interests in negotiation?
options: Positions are what people want; interests are why they want it
